author: handhand

title: Snap together mini lamp - Light Attachment

description.text:
I created a small light attachment, which is battery operated, and fits into the head of the lamp.
If you have an existing printed version of the lamp, you can add this to it, pretty easily.  You may need a dremel tool to extract away a little of the plastic, so you can add the switch and mount the little light. This is what I did.

I've created multiple pictures of the process of soldering, cutting wires, and adding the LEDs to a round PCB, which you can get from Radio Shack to build this little light.  
The light works with a little switch in back, and works quite well really.
It's not to heavy, because it uses button batteries, (four of them) at 1.5 volts to provide power.
From Radio Shack you can buy a Micromini SPDT switch from Radio shack 275-0635 is the model I used, as it fits pretty well.  Then you'll need some wire. I used 16 gauge wire for mine. Then you can get a round PCB Kit from Radio shack. 276-004 is the model on that.
The only thing you'll need to fine is then sheet metal, which you can get from home depot, or maybe radio shack, i just happen to have some I took from some old electronics.  You'll need that for the battery case. Then last, but not least, you'll need LEDs.  I'm a bit strange, as I have hundreds of these around for other projects i'm doing, but you can order them online, or pick them up from an Radio Shack or an electronics store.  I included a picture of the back of 800 I have of the type i used, which were small LEDS, but you could use pretty much any LED you want.
The button batteries I used are: 386A 1.5v from micro center, used to replace LR43, 386, G12 and 186, according to the package.
The case I have here that you print will hold all the electronics and fit right into the lamp.
I'll post some additional detailed instructions on my website later, with more detail.

title: Angled Rail V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
To see the updated version click here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:868856 This angled rail attachment will make it possible for you to mount iron-sights angled, mount your flashlight or laser angled as well, to keep them out of the way. Purchased a print from shapeways, so I could see how well it would fit, and to take some pictures. I can see now that this is far from a finished design, and can become much easier to print, and make it more strong and durable. I have now finally finished it! Its now a V2! Sorry to you guys that waited for me to update the model. I originally made it in blender, but it was so much of a pain in the butt, that I just kind of ignored it. Until now where I have my Autodesk Inventor :-D and everything is so easy to make compared, to blender xD Hope you find this thing useful :-) The Version 1 (V1) does not have a proper locking mechanism. I kept it on if someone still would like to have a download available.
If you would like me to make any changes, just comment on this thing :-)

The lock mechanism has a slight adjustment option.
Since the "Screw" has a tread at the end, to make a tighter fit, just screw the "Screw" a half or hole revolution in or out, to get the "Lock" closer or further from the mount.

description.text: Here is an enclosure for an Arduino Uno that I designed in Tinkercad. I have printed it, and it works pretty well, although I really want to rearrange or redo the holes so that they line up neatly with the header pins. It does make a nifty little home for an Arduino, if you have yours sitting on your desk all day like I do. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/goyPxkdQ46U

Print both halves and join them. Let me know if you have problems. Feel free to go on Tinkercad and modify your own version of it - Mark it as a derivative, I would love to see it :) FYI - this is based off this version which I designed as well: https://tinkercad.com/things/aeeotgSaQ1x-shapely-arduino-enclosure-print That one should work too - I just printed the bottom half. I wanted to use less plastic, so I made this version. Also the cuts along the snapfit make it easier to get this version open. I could not have made it without the fantastic work of Mikko's Arduino Box model, which I used for the model of the Uno itself: https://tinkercad.com/things/gj927lPLv2P-arduino-box

author: handhand

description.text: I am moving this design off of Thingiverse in protest of their attempt to patent designs originally conceived by the 3D printing community. This file can now be found on Repables at http://repables.com/r/286/ and Github at https://github.com/sgraber/Minecraft_Wither-Fully_Articulated. For more information, please see the following article: http://www.openbeamusa.com/blog/2014/5/22/stay-classy-makerbot #makerbot, #takerbot My son and his friend requested a Minecraft Wither, with the ability to move all three heads. I wanted it a nice size - not too big, not too small. However with printed pins, it limits the minimum size of a model as I've found small pins tend to wear over the long term. In the end, I decided to try using LEGO Technic pins, which my son has a LOT of sitting in his LEGO assembly cabinet. If you need a bunch, you can find them on Amazon or Ebay for $10 for ~300 pins. All in all, this assembly method turned out VERY well. I've printed two of these Withers on my i3 and they fit together nicely. The pins snap in solidly and they hold the parts just about as well as in normal LEGO bricks. I took inspiration for this project from "arthurtilly" and his Tiny Wither: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:320990

I print all of my parts with a 0.4mm nozzle, three perimeters, 0.25mm layer height, 20% infill, at 195C / 65C (extruder / hbp).  
I print the face parts with the faces pointing up and the body laying on its back, in combination with support using Cura.  You may need to reorient the parts before printing so they are facing in the appropriate direction...  
NOTE: All parts were modeled in Inventor and STLs were exported for printing.

author: specialteacher

title: Mendel vitamin-less Y-carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In the spririt of the original Darwin this is a Y-carriage that uses virtually no vitamins other than two threaded rods and some machine screws.  
The rods are just off-cuts from the lengths you use to build your printer so they won't even cost you anything.  
Designed to take a standard Prusa-200x200 pcb-type hot bed which mount at 210mm centres (these heaters are cool at the corners so will be fine with a PLA printed carriage).  
Utilises four of my unbreakable LM8UU bearing holders.  
For 5mm threaded rods use the version "YCMax3_5mm".

Print out two ends YCMax3.STL plus four bearing holders LM8UUB.STL
2 perimeters, 2 base layers, 25% fill.
This has been designed to the maximum printable size and just fits on a 200x200 printer bed. Use a skirt 2mm away and it will fit with 45 degrees rotation. Requires:
2 x 150mm long 8mm rods (or 6" of equivalent imperial rod)
4 x M8 nuts
4 x 8mm washers
12 x M3x20 machine screws
4 x M3x25 machine screws (for bearing holders)
16 x M3 nuts
4 x LM8UU bearings Mount the four bearing holders, two per carriage half, with 2 x M3x20 machine screws and nuts. The M3 screws can be used either way around but I went for the nuts on top to save having to trim the screws to fit. Mount the belt clamps with 2 x M3x20 machins screws and nuts each. Fit one LM8UU bearing per bearing holder and secure in position with an M3x25 machine screw and M3 nut. Bolt the two halves together and space them to give an overall measurement of 210mm between pcb heater mounting holes (it is easier to set this up finger-tight then mount it on the y-rails before final tightening). Install the carriage on the Y-axis rails and then systematically tighten the M8 nuts checking for easy movement as you go.

remixed_from.author: MoonCactus
remixed_from.title: GoPro customizable mounts, and a library to expand

description.text:
This is a fully printable GoPro line mount for your kite. http://youtu.be/k5zBLl5FX6Q
Easily mount your GoPro camera on the center lines of your kite. I had in mind the newer model, Hero 3+, but it will work for the Hero 3 too with some processing. I used the Hero 3, to place the camera inside the base and had in mind that the 3+ is smaller. So you may need to trim some plastic from the top connection There are two versions. The one we actually used is the white ABS one. The top connection allows bending, while the bottom slim connection does not. You can print it with the bottom connection and if it breaks remove it. The test made with the bottom connection already broken. In order to mount it on the lines, i used 4 nylon clips. I was extra cautious on the line mounts, so that the lines won't wear from contact with the base. The clips are not pressing the lines too tight, but are holding the base on it's position. I printed a slim version with nylon (Taulman 645), but it didn't stick well on the bed and the line mounts are messed up. Although i believe that nylon is the way to go. Since this is in beta version and i don't own a GoPro, i would be happy if i got some feedback from kiters on windy days :)
Our video (on it's way) was shot with little wind so it's just a "walk" on the sea. Warning: Always tie your camera on the kite's lines or somewhere else in case of failure. I'm not responsible for any loss. Many thanks to brentb and MoonCactus for their designs.

Print the base. I printed the base on ABS and it worked well.
Nylon is also another option.
The one we tested is the thick, gopro_v22-ABS.stl. You will need to trim some plastic at the line mounts, in order to smooth the path of the line. Print 4 clips.
If you select the slim version, print the clip_11.stl.
For the thicker base print clip15_new.stl.
Clips were printed with nylon. I have not tried yet to print them with other materials, that are stiffer. When printing with nylon make sure it's dried for good. If it's not dried well, the clips will be even more flexible and you may have problems mounting the base.

title: Smily Cookie cutter and stamp, With Improved Script!

description.text: A boring old circle cookie cutter made FUN with a smily stamp! This includes the openscad script used to create it, so you too can make cool cookie cutters :-) Thank you profezzorn for showing me how to handle layers in a dxf file! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29247 I have tweaked the script so that the stamp now fits into the cutter and the bits that you draw turn up as raised lumps in the cookie.

To make a smily cookie, download the STL and print both parts. Next make a batch of cookie dough. this site has a great recipe: thehungryhousewife.com/2009/10/sugar-cookie-and-icing-tips.html . Roll thin, cut out the circle, before removing the cutter push the smily stamp firmly onto the cookie. Bake and eat! If you want to create your own cookie cutter you will need:
OpenSCAD
An image editor that can export to DXF (I use inkscape) First edit the SVG file to make your own image. The CC layer will be transformed into the Cookie Cutter.
The Stamp layer will be transformed into the stamp. Any filled regions will appear as raised bumps on your cookies. Massage both layers into a workable form and save as a DXF (look at repraprip.blogspot.co.nz/2011/05/inkscape-to-openscad-dxf-tutorial.html for instructions) You will need to edit the CookieCutter2.scad file. The OpenSCAD script has two important routines, cookiecutter() and stamp(). You need to run each of these separately, commenting out the one you don't need. Once you have generated The cutter and stamp, print them, take photos and post them up on Thingiverse!

These heel wedges are to help correct Pronation/Supination of the foot. See diagrams for explanation.  
I have slight supination in my right foot from an injury and will only be using the lowest angle wedge. I'm not medically trained so cannot recommend using these wedges especially if you have pronounced pronation/supination.  
Use at your own risk!

I suggest gluing these to the bottom of a soft insole before putting in your shoe. If your shoe is contoured you can mold the insert into the shape of your shoe by warming it first. I have added three different sizes:
small 37EU, 4UK, 4 1/2US
medium 42EU, 7 1/2UK, 8US
large 46EU, 11 1/2UK, 12US
The sizes aren't exact. I've also done 4 different degrees of angle 2,3,6 and 9. All the files are called supination but the design is symetrical so if you have pronation in your right foot just use the left foot supination file.

Cresent Moon Keychain
Can be used as a keychain or just a thingy

It's a hexagon chain mail thing.
Each chain is connected to 3 other chain elements. Most chain mails I have seen have a quadratic form and 4 connecting neighbors. I found one triangle version with 3 connecting neighbors, too. They are listed as ancestors, because the ideas are similar.

Make changes to OpenScad-file's parameters, resize it, print it, separate each chain carefully. You might want to resize the 20x20 mesh to fit it to your printer plate.
Or you can delete some elements using Meshlab to make a chain (sf_big_chain.stl).
Using Meshlab:
  • Open file / import your mesh
  • find + push the "select connected components in a region" button
  • use your mouse to select an element to delete
  • press delete on your keyboard
  • repeat that with other element of the chainmail
  • file/export mesh as ...

I reworked this model from another model i found on thingiverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:190146) It appeared that i had to move a little bit the fixing holes so that i can fit this part without forcing on the part. I also enlarged a little bit the pneufit hole so that it's a little bit easier to fit inside.
You might require to force a little bit though as you want your pneufit connector to stay put. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/7mwkRvWQS9S

I reworked this connector from another model found inside the original openbeam 1.4 models. I removed the hex nut hole and i added a hole on the top so that you can use standard 1/8" push fit connectors. For those who look for those parts here are some ebay links:
http://www.ebay.fr/itm/Pneumatic-Straight-Push-Fitting-1-8-of-All-Metal-J-head-bowden-extruder-RepRap-/271455428724?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&var=&hash=item3f34012074 where you can select either 4mm inner diameter for 4mm ptfe tubes that will let you use 1.75mm filaments
or 6mm inner diameter for 6mm ptfe tubes required for 3mm filaments. Just a little warning about push fit connectors dimensions,
The inches are pneumatic/hydrolic inches which are different from imperial inches. This might be useful consideration for people used to metric system units. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/5AmyyIGl8jN

title: The Dark Knight Ping Pong Ball

description.text: We had to write text or print objects or both on the ping pong ball on the eggbot for DFab. I decided to do the famous line from The Dark Knight, "Why so Serious?".

First I opened up the template for the project on inkscape, then I typed out my text in my selected font and adjusted it so it was in the middle and bigger. Then I went to path>object to path and then path>combine to outline the text so it would print out correctly on the Eggbot. Then I got out thye Eggbot machine hooked it up and put the ball in the rubber part of the machine that holds the object. After that I adjusted the pen into the hole, then from the program adjusted it's height from extensions>eggbot>eggbot control. Then I was done with that soI just hit the apply button and let it print. After it printed I made sure it looked okay and turned out the way I wanted it to and I was done.
Also I wouldn't use the EPS file because it doesn't come out like it's supposed to in Illustrator.

When the MakerBot Store (298 Mulberry Street in Manhattan) first opened, we had to prop open the door. The existing doorstop was the style that had a hook and a loop, but this was on the inside of the store, and we needed to prop the door open outward because of a temporary issue with the gate. To solve this issue, we designed, printed, tested, and then revised the design to make a taller than average doorstop. The first one was too short so a new one had to be made. This was a great use of a MakerBot ReplicatorÃ¢âÂ¢2 Desktop 3D Printer! Created by Todd.

Version 1 is smaller than Version 2.  Version 2 is taller, and is the one we ended up using.
-Todd

comments.text: Im printing it right now on the Da Vinci Pro.  Just watch the XYZware program and make sure it slices the item right before printing... I had to reload it and make it re-slice a couple times because it would do odd things like make the little round part solid instead of hollow... the printer is okay, just wish I could use different software. I printed the first half already and have just started on the other half. I did find after the fact that I could have printed both at the same time as I was able to manipulate the angles to fit them both on the heated bed... live and learn.

comments.text:
Creo is only the CAD Program. You'll aditionally need an slicer. It's a program that prepairs your model for 3d Printing.
I use Creo myself and it works great to construct models to 3d print but it doesn't prepare it for the Printer.

comments.text: Hey man! Just got two new printers in our school and i'm going to print this bad boy. But since i'm new to this could you explain why printing two half's is better than one whole piece? Does it take any longer or shorter time due to which of the two ways you print it with? And last but not least, is there anything crucial I need to know before making this? So there's isn't any failiures or anything.
comments.author: Sazzow

comments.text:
Hey!
The best way is to print in two parts for saving plastic. Otherwise you have to print with support and will take more time to print. After you have printed out both pieces you need to glue them together. If your printer doesn't have a heated bed should you look out for warping at the tip of the knife! You can solve this by printing with the "brim" tool (brim adds a single layer around you object so it get more stuck on the building plate).

Here are the 92 Johnson Polyhedron-Dual Compounds. The openSCAD files are collected in Johnson_Compounds_Scad.zip and a selection of the stl files is in Johnson_Compounds_Stl.zip. The dual stl files described in thing:32101 were converted to polyhedron commands to speed computation. The Johnson polyhedra are varied, some are not very symmetric, and in fact some of the compounds are ugly. However 8 of the Johnson polyhedra have vertices
which are equidistant from the origin, (J27, J34, J37, J72, J73, J74, J75, and J80), and their compounds resemble the Archimedean-Catalan compounds. Elongated Johnson polyhedral compounds often have interesting belts or end caps. Attractive ones are: J35, J38, J42, J43, J46, and J48. The truncated cubes and dodecahedrons, J66, J67, J68, and J69 are fairly attractive and should make nice 2 color prints. The rhombicosidodecahedrons, J76, J77, J78, and J79 are interesting compounds with a single downward spike. Sample stl files are: compound_J27.stl
compound_j34.stl
compound_J37.stl
compound_J74.stl
compound_j35.stl
compound_j38.stl
compound_j67.stl
compound_j68.stl

Compounds J27, J34, J37, J74, and J38 need to be printed with external support.  They are well handled by my Replicator.  Compounds J35, J67, and j68 have clear flat faces.  They can be printed directly on the build platform.
OpenSCAD has two commands which are useful for a study of these compounds; color and animate.  All of the openSCAD files use color to distinguish the polyhedron from its dual. Color works in compile mode.
One parameter that needs to be set for constructing a compound is the scale between the polyhedron and its dual.  The animate command in the view menu can help with this.  A scale factor can be varied over a range with the animate command.  Compound_j35_animate.scad contains an example of this feature.  Load it in openSCAD, invoke animate and enter 16 in FPS  and 250 in Steps.  The polyhedron will swell to subsume the dual.

A cupholder for the driver of a Peugeot 5008 that takes a big cup. Fits into the central oddment compartment. This car has a central cupholder for the middle seats that only takes a small cup, one each side for the rear fold-up seats but nothing at all for the driver!

Situation now rectified, use at your own risk etc, etc.

title: A Few Bits for Emmett's Minimalistic Mk8 replacement

description.text: I wrote this little headache-style OpenSCAD because I didn't have the right springs but a few ones from these: http://reprapworld.com/?products_details&products_id=228&cPath=1591_1618 (9 coils of 1mm wire diameter for a total lenght of 25mm with an 10mm OD and 8mm, ID) Bearings were also an issue, the only ones I had where some scavenged from old milling cutting tools (5x9.5x3.2 or something like).

Unfortunatelly, there's quite some work after printing, check out the PDF for the details.
2x Flat Head Machine Screws are required for each spring I used M3x10mm, a little bit longer should be also ok.
For the bearing I also used another M3x10mm and due to the dimensions of those bearings I found, I also used 2x M3 washers (not to eliminate but to decrease the gap up to a minimum.
You shouldn't need the tubes/bushings/shells/whatever if you use the right bearings. 
Do not force anything* or you'll end up breaking it, use the OpenSCAD (full of parameters) if something doesn't fit.
(*) The only place where force MUST carefully be done is to mount the springs.
The STL available for download are arranged in sets for 1 or 2 extruders (there's no left and right here).

This is a model of the skeleton of an airplane wing. This is purely for artistic purpose and is not meant to be flown.

• Download .ai file or .eps file
  • Print to CNC laser with the following settings
  • Raster Speed: 100%
  • Raster Power: 50%
  • Vector Speed: 12%
  • Vector Power: 100%
  • Vector Frequency: 5000
  • This piece was made on 3mm acrylic
  • When assembling piece use acrylic glue
    • Print the Model Airplane Wing. Place the ribs so that the indentations match up with the large rectangular wing base. Place two ribs on ether end of the wing base and glue them on using acrylic glue. Then glue one rib in the center of the wing, after this is done glue the last two ribs at the midpoint between the far and center ribs. Once all of the ribs are glued to the base, place the rib brace through the hole in the ribs and glue it at the ends.

author: charlespayne

description.text: This ancient statue confirms the one-time existence of a dreaded Greek tyrant lizard-human. #TRexRemix
123D Catch and Tinkercad mostly...

I took guru\'s very cool OpenSCAD file, cleaned it up, made it fully parametric, and fiddled with the parameters. Specifically, the following parameters are different:
  • I made the rings a bit thicker so the build quality is improved.
  • The number of rings is now adjustable, and they are arranged in a circle.
  • I played with the tilt of the rings and the distance between them so they didn\'t overlap. (necessary, since they are now bigger)
  • The tor versions have had the cylinder section replaced with a toroid and have been further tweaked.
    • The ideal offset between rings could probably be calculated, but I don\'t feel like thinking that hard just right now. (Maybe in a future revision.) I\'ve included here 3 and 7 ring sets. Up to 7 can be made before the first and last rings overlap. The toroid version has been tweaked so that 10 rings can fit and make a complete circle. Guru\'s original design makes the ring out of a section of a cylinder, and I have left that version in the file. I have included a torus (revolved circle) version of the ring as well. However, the torus version, due to the slightly smaller perimeter, has a slightly worse surface finish. (I may tweak this and try a larger diameter later.)

Use the existing sets, or play with the parameters and make your own.
(If you find a combination of parameters that makes a nice non-overlapping set of a different number or size, post it!) I\'ll add other combinations here if people ask. Note that this model may tickle bugs in the skeinforge-0006 fill and towering modules. The fill bug may cause some segments to be unnecessarily solid. Interaction between the fill bug and towering bug may cause the head to pass through a previous tower. One of my revisions had this problem, but the 3 ring version here seemed to work OK. (In other words, watch your build in case something goes wrong!) The torus version has a slightly worse overhang than the cylinder version. Oddly, it seems to handle it better and sags less anyway. I couldn't get skeinforge-0006 to slice ringsN10tor.stl at all. Version 7 seemed to work, but I haven't tried to build it yet. Note that this build is within 3mm of the full platform size, and may cause the head to move over the screws.

author: ajayre

description.text:
Another in my series of pencil/pen/marker/brush holders.  
I know what you are thinking, "Why is the STL file just a block?"  Well, yeah.  It -is- just a block. And any block will do.  
This pencil holder is more about technique than modeling.  Just model up any rectangular block that is the size that you need.  
Set the infill to 7% or 8% with 2 shells.  
When you are printing, just cancel the print before it prints the top layers to your block.  Voila!  A pencil holder, with slots for each pencil, that you didn't spend any time modeling up.  
Tips:  Stick to rectangular blocks, as they have the most clear cells.  Try rotating the block 60 degrees to the left or the right while slicing to see which orientation results in the most usable cells.

The most important bit is to set the infill to 7% for fat pens or 8% for pencils and such.  
The rest is up to your personal preferences.

I did this chicken in clay. Today I tried 123 Catch which only worked half, so I used the ok half to reconstruct the chicken, sculped it and then printed it. Only small, fast and without infill so it is more a test of printability, terrible surfaces and holes on slopes. Used "Pillar" Support of slic3r which worked.

Der Stabilisator wird unten mit der original Schraube der Extruder-Befestigungsplatte festgeschraubt (und zwar OHNE die Beilagscheibe).

comments.text:
Really depends on what software you're using I guess. The pretty powerful (and $$) software I used has a cutting tool where I can select the part to be cut, and then select a plane (or other object) with which to cut it. I'd check your manual, there is usually some form of this in the software (but they don't always make the easy things easy!).
In the absence of that however, the other tool you might have available, and I have used with this, is some sort of Boolean operation. You can usually construct primitives (cubes/spheres/cones) and copies of your part to systematically isolate each half of an intended cut. Hope that helps, if even just a little!

I quickly got sick of bending over with a flashlight to get a good look at my prints. I was hoping to use those easy 3M LED light strips, but with the shape of the Rostock platform, they just weren't going to work.
My first rev used regular 20mA white LEDs but the heat from the hotend caused the leds to fail one-by-one until they were all gone or flickering.
I landed on some 1-watt LEDs that I'm running at a lower "wattage". I tried them cranked all the way up, but 3 at full power was absolutely blinding.

Required:
  • 3 x 1-watt LED lights (http://www.amazon.com/microtivity-IL726-1-watt-Ultra-bright-White/dp/B0085MOZYW/ref=sr_1_2?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1350344791&sr=1-2&keywords=microtivity+1-watt+led)
  • hookup wire
  • A resistor (depends on your preference). Lowest value you can go with 3 LEDS wired in a series like these is 8.2ohm. I landed on 33ohm, as these are super bright and the full 3 watts was blinding.
    • Look at the pictures, but it's pretty simple. Wire these in series with the resistor on the positive side. Additionally, I used a 1/4" drill bit to clean out the LED holes. NOTE: DO NOT connect these LEDs to a power source without a resistor. If you'd like a softer look, take some sand paper and gently rub the outer plastic lens. It'll diffuse the light softening it. I printed this in polycarbonate so I used pseudo support because regular support attaches to your finished print and PC is way too strong for that.

comments.text: What do you mean by connecting a resistor to the set up? I'm not very savy with electronics so could you explain more on that?
comments.author: EJ_K

comments.text: The LED's need a lower voltage than the one you will get from the power supply, the rambo board, or even piggy backing the fan. The resisters will help reduce the voltage and allow the LED to work without burning out. If you aren't sure about this, you can find ring lights with the piggy back wire splitter online for $10 - 15.

On my homebuilt Rostock, I use that flat 30A PSU and no PWM(PID) for my hotend and the LEDs light up w/o issue. However, when using the PSU on my RostockMAX, which uses a regular computer PSU and the hotend using PID temp controller, I find that when the arduino is pulsing the voltage to the hotend, it causes the lights to flicker slightly in sync with the LED flashing on the arduino.

description.text: Handle and handle body to fix a delonghi coffee steam handle that had snapped off. Unit is woth $1600 new and the replacement parts for the steamer were $400...! Enter the printrbot and some good old fashioned making.

Take off the front cover to reveal the steamer unit fixed to the inside. Print off the handle body and handle. Trim both so they look nice! Tap the handle body onto the spine of the steamer unit, noting that the hollow will allow the support to fit along the unit as well. Once it is firmly attached you will most likely need to tap it gently with a rubber mallet to dribe it home. Once attached you can drill through it and add an M3 screw for added torsional strength. Replace cover. Attach handle by using a plasterboard or wood screw driven through handle into the body. Turn on. Heat up, Steam that milk!

title: british old time freight car, H0 scale

description.text: My son got Thomas the tank engine for his third birthday... and of course Annie and Clarabel, the passenger cars. But he also wanted to have some freight cars, too. So daddy improved his OpenSCAD skills and designed a matching freight car. And here it is for all of you! It prints as a kit with 21 parts and it's quite a lot of work to clean all the parts and put them together, but in the end you get a nice working model. The cars are very light, so it is useful to add some weight to prevent derailing.
Have a look at the colored image to see where all the parts are located. I used PLA to print and CA glue to put the parts together. My axles and coupler bolts were made from 1mm brass wire.

title: Lightning Dock Adapter Support for iPhone 5

description.text: Apple sells an adapter for your dock's electronics, but I wanted something that would support my iPhone 5 a bit more securely.

1 - Get yourself an iPhone 5.
2 - Get one of Apple's Lightning Dock Adapters.
3 - Print one of these.
4 - Attach the Apple Lightning Dock Adapter inside the opening using the adhesive of your choice.
(Tip: Connect the adapter to you iPhone during this step to assure proper alignment.) Optional: A little careful Dremel work to remove the latching dimples on the sides of the lightning connector will make it easier to slide the phone on and off the dock adapter - gravity will keep it in place.

title: Eagle Mask
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The Eagle Mask was designed for ThreeForm performers at Maker Faire. Now you can print it at home for Halloween or other events. This version has been redesigned for extrusion printers that lack soluble support material. A version with a support piece has been added for increased reliability. It has wall thickness of 2mm in the thin areas and 4mm in the thick areas. It occupies two cubic inches of volume. A small ThreeForm logo has been added on the cheek area, not shown in the renderings.

Scale it, print it out, and fasten with an elastic string. This mask was designed from scan data of a young woman with a 5.35" temple width. The design is somewhat forgiving, but it is better to have it oversized than undersized. I recommend scaling it up for your own temple width, plus 1%. A flexible (and easily paintable)SLS nylon version is available on Shapeways here: Eagle Mask - http://www.shapeways.com/model/734630/eagle-mask.html Two other lightweight mask designs are also currently available: Venetian Mask - http://www.shapeways.com/model/734631/venetian-mask.html DareDevil Mask - http://www.shapeways.com/model/734623/daredevil-mask.html

A general purpose 2" c-clamp utilizing a M8x50mm bolt.
The frame of the clamp was downloaded from a public CAD library and modified to house the matching M8 nut to accompany the bolt.
There is a swivel pad threaded to the end of the bolt which required support material for my built.  Once the support was disolved, the two halves of the swivel were gently seperated with a pair of pliers.

Hardware:
  • M8x60 bolt
  • M8 nut
  • Cyanoacrylate adhesive
  • Two pair of pliers
    • Printing:
  • Frame: print it flat to maintain the strength of the frame.
  • Handle: designed to accept the hex of a M8 bolt
  • Nut Cover: used to retain the nut that will be glued to the frame.
  • Swivel Pad: printed with support and has M8 threads already modeled in.
    • Assembly
  • Press the nut deep into the hex hole of the frame. The nut should sit 2mm below the hole edge.
  • Glue in the nut cover.
  • Thread the bolt into the frame.
  • Remove the support material from the swivel pad.
  • Using two pliers grip both halves of the swivel pad assembly and gently twist the two in opposite directions to free the two parts.
  • Thread the swivel pad onto the bolt...no need to glue
  • Glue the handle to the hex head of the bolt.

description.text:
Overview
===
This is a basic fastener called a roll pin, slotted spring pin, or tension pin. These are designed to replace M3 screws that various projects require in places where a alloy steel screw is overkill/too heavy etc etc. The pins are hollow cylinders with a slot or slit placed longitudinally that allows for compression during insertion and should equally distribute stress throughout the screw hole. Please take note: One end of the pin is beveled. This goes into the hole first. This allows for easier insertion than a blunt pin... Specifications
===
The pin has been designed to have an outer diameter (OD) of 3.4mm and inner diameter (ID) of 2.0mm. The pin has a thickness (measured between the outside and inside) of 0.75mm. Holes with a diameter of 3.1-3.2mm will work very well. 3.0mm holes will be extremely tight and you run the risk of breaking the pin or ripping the hole out of the piece your fitting. The clearance for a M3 screw hole is 3.2mm for a close fit and 3.4mm for a medium fit according to the charts I referenced. Files
===
There are .stl files for single pins in standard sizes from 4mm-16mm. Final Thought
===
Unlike its steel counterpart this PLA pin is non-reusable. If you need to repin/remove a pinned part you will need to use a punch (as you would a steel pin) which will likely destroy/mangle the pin... This really isn't a big deal since you can print a tons, its just the nature of the medium we are working with and the forces it can sustain. Also, removal without a proper 3mm punch is likely to be a tad frustrating ;)

I printed using: .25mm layer, 4 shells and 120mm/sec @ 230 degrees on a MakerBot Replicator 2 with no support or raft (on duck brand blue painters tape).  You might be better off printing @ .2mm due to the dimension changes I made in version 2 but it still printed fine at .25mm.  
Printing single pins seems to work fine without overheating of the small part (at least on the MakerBot) but it doesn't take very long to print a dozen.

title: Parametric lens filter ring adaptor and base for LED ring

description.text:
I found a set of 62mm macro filters (+1, +2, +4 diopters) at a surplus store. They are 62mm filter ring size. My lens are 52, 58, and 67mm... So, I designed this parametric adaptor with an optional platform for a white LED ring I found at the same store. The model can generate built in supports for 3d printing. Currently untested, it will be a week before I can work on it.

After using simple 1/2 inch PVC conduit as blowguns in a Nerf war, I figured I could print up a revolver to increase my firing rate. Designed for Nerf N-Strike darts (up to 80mm length, 15mm diameter), this revolver fits six darts and can fire them one after the other (it's a blowgun, for simplicity and accuracy). It's designed to fit snugly onto a nominal 1/2-inch PVC conduit pipe (21mm OD, 3mm wall thickness), and uses 10 4x1.5mm neodymium disc magnets to lock the chambers into alignment. Known issues
  • If the end piece is printed airtight, when firing, some air may leak into the adjacent dart chambers and cause them to blow out of the chamber towards you.
  • The tolerances on the parts cause air to leak out in general, reducing the effective range of the weapon. Could possibly be improved by adding O-rings.

Print all four parts.  Glue the magnets into the holes in the chamber and end pieces (taking care to orient them properly so that the chamber and end pieces attract when put together).
Use 8 of the M3 screws you have left over from your Makerbot (or any screws about that size will do) to fasten the mouth, cover, and end pieces together, and use 2 more to loosely hold the chamber piece in.  The chamber should rotate freely and then magnetically lock into position.
Cut a length of 1/2 inch PVC conduit (2-3 feet works pretty well).  You can put a coupler in the middle to allow easy storage, plus it converts into two short blowguns in a pinch.

title: Tube Collar Locks Dust Filter Plate

description.text:
This will allow the tubes on the caps to stay stationary when twisting the caps off for easy removal of filament for your Flashforge,CTC and Wanhao dual printers. Here is link to the source.
Plate and Cap: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:312726
Cap with Grips: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:325551 Test: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n9Z02SJvH1o Installed: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xul_M9r4U0I Cable holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:287253 Update:
5/13/2014 Added cap with grips 12/31/2014 Combined threads to this designed cable guide from, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:340031

Printed in abs 20% fill 235C. I used my filament fan when printing out this collars part. White tube measures 1/4 inch and black tube measures 7/32 inch . Used a 9/32 inch drill bit to drill out the caps for the white tube and use a 1/4 inch drill bit to drill out the caps for the black. Update:
5/13/2014 When printing cap with grips print out one cap at a time. Settings on printer where infill 20% extrude temp 230C, Bed temp 110C and turn in filament fan if your machine has one. Makes grips turn out nice and clean.

remixed_from.author: zerocool5878
remixed_from.title: Upper and Lower Z Mounts for AO MendelMax 10mm rods

title: Parametric lower Z (motor) mounts for AO / MendelMax printers

description.text:
I really like the AO-100 style motor mounts, but ran into challenges editing the STLs for some of the things I was trying to do (e.g. testing different rod sizes, adding a membrane on the rod mount screw holes to improve the print).  
I put this together loosely based on the AO design to make it easier for me to tweak.  
Please note that this is a complete redesign -- though I'm happily also releasing under the GPL, and really appreciate the Lulzbot design.  Also while I've tried to make sure that the height will match their design (such that lead screws, etc. will work seamlessly), I haven't replicated some of the other measurements (e.g. horizontal hole spacing, length of the motor mounting slots, etc.) I also didn't replicate the mechanical stop activator, as I'm using a different style of Z limit switch.  
So far my testing has been limited -- I recommend verifying measurements for yourself before investing a lot of effort in printing & using these... though I have put in effort to get things right.  If you have issues or suggestions, let me know and I'm happy to try and get things sorted.

I've been printing with ABS @ 0.2mm height, with 0.7 or more infill -- I know this is more solid than most people will need, however.  
As with similar mount designs, you will need 2 each of the motor mounts & clamps.  
In the scad source you can easily tweak for other rod diameters, change spacing, etc.  It should also be -relatively- straightforward to change to NEMA23 or other motors & do other customizations, though I didn't make a point to simplify those things.  (ok, after playing with that for a sec, NEMA23 may be a bit more of a challenge due to shaft alignment & limited distance to the frame - but you get the idea).  
Note that this requires the OpenSCAD MCAD libraries (units & boxes) -- these should come with any reasonably recent OpenSCAD release.

comments.text:
Absolutely lovely parametric design - checked it and you did a great job.
Though there is one minor flaw - you can't insert the nut for the rod mounting block anywhere. ;)

description.text: 9 volt batteries are useful items to include in your hiking, camping, and survival gear. When touched to a wad of steel wool you have an INSTANT hot starter fire. The thing is, you want to protect those exposed terminals from contact with anything that might short out and drain the battery. This original design cap does just that. The small enclosure on the inside further isolates and protects the positive terminal. Apply a small amount of caulk around the base of the cap and it is totally waterproofed as well. Enjoy! I make these on a 3D CUBE printer using ABS plastic. Print time is about 50 minutes.
